Titanic.passage: "Titanic was a British passenger and cargo ship that sank in the North Atlantic Ocean in the early morning of April 15, 1912, after striking an iceberg during its maiden voyage from Southampton to New York City. Of the 2,229 passengers and crew, 1,523 perished, and a further 1,026 perished later. Titanic was a symbol of the new era in aviation and marine engineering, and the event has since come to be regarded as a defining event of the 20th century. The Titanic's story, from its first conception to the moment of its demise, is the subject of several well-documented books by authors such as E.A. Smith, John Rettman, Thomas Andrews, Richard Frost, and Stephen D. Clark. The 1956 film Titanic was directed by James Cameron and starred Leonardo DiCaprio. Many songs and other media such as television series and video games are also based on the story. Titanic has been the subject of various documentaries and re-enactments, and the wreckage of the ship has been the focus of a number of expeditions over the years. Titanic became a lasting icon for the era in which it was lost, and its story has captured the imagination of generations. The Titanic was a British passenger liner and maritime disaster that sank in the North Atlantic Ocean in the early morning of April 15, 1912.

E.A. Smith.passage: Edwin Aron Smith (1887 – July 22, 1939) was a British writer and poet, whose works include the novels The Black Prince, and The Way. He was born Edwin Arthur Smith in Bexhill, Sussex, and wrote his first novel at the age of twelve. During his lifetime he wrote 35 other books and over 300 poems. Edwin Aron Smith's works are considered to be the result of a highly developed imagination, as well as his profound personal struggles. Though most of his novels were written during the first world war, his works are characterized as pre-Tennessee Williams, post-Gothic, and in the spirit of Dostoevski. Smith's works include novels, poems, essays, and plays. The Way, in particular, has been noted for its use of the modernist and surrealist narrative techniques, and its themes of loss, death, and a descent into insanity. He is regarded as a significant poet of the twentieth century. The Way is a book by E.A. Smith which is a collection of 21 short stories which are written in a post-Gothic manner. It is mainly made up of tales of the death of a man and his journey through a dream world. The Black Prince is a collection of seven short stories written by E.A. Smith.

Southampton.passage:
"Southampton (
/ˈsɒnth(ə)p(ə)l/ (help · listen)
) is a port city on the south coast of England. It has the fourth-largest economy in the country after the three London-based financial centres. History
The area has been populated for thousands of years. The harbour was established by the Romans in the 1st century AD. The city name originates from the name of the Celtic-speaking Roman settlement built near the River Thames called "Hampton". During the Middle Ages, the city was the centre of the Roman Catholic Church in England, which made it a centre of shipbuilding and maritime trade. Southampton also became the centre of cloth trade and, as such, Southampton became known as "Soton" (or "Southend") and the largest seaport in the world. During the Industrial Revolution the city became the world's biggest centre for trade in Southampton-manufactured goods. Southampton's prosperity was helped by its location on the South Coast near the Isle of Wight. After the Industrial Revolution the city was established as a centre for the production of shipbuilding materials such as rope. Southampton's prosperity was further enhanced by the discovery in 1798 of oil and natural gas at the nearby oil fields and the establishment of a number of refineries to extract the resources.

qae_pairs.question: What are the ships that sank on the voyage from Southampton to the Isle of Wight in 1912?
